comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Relevant map showing intersection of George Street [left], Cumberland Street [centre], and Lower Fort Street [right] - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367463.html

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/] Thanks for posting this. It is a wonderful forgotten corner of 'Old Sydney', obliterated for the Sydney Harbour Bridge southern approach. GoogleMapsStreetView - maps.google.com.au/maps?q=Sydney+NSW&hl=en&ll=-33...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] The building called "Catholic Presbytery" on your map is of great interest. It is 'Cumberland Place' (not to be confused with the alleyway of the same name!) and best known as the home of Dr James Mitchell. Built by Francis Greenway in 1825; demolished c.1912. More info, photos and famous paintings of the property - collection.hht.net.au/firsthhtpictures/fullRecordPicture.... acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=430971# acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=412822#

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Brilliant! David Scott Mitchell's (of Mitchell Library fame) childhood home. He lived there until 1871 when his mother died. More "Cumberland Place" images - www.photosau.com.au/cos/scripts/ExtSearch.asp?SearchTerm=... www.printsandprintmaking.gov.au/catalogues/work/51307/lio... And here's your virtual prize for being the first to tag The Stror 'At Coot! - aso.gov.au/titles/features/sentimental-bloke/clip2/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Luvvs it, I does! Thankee kindlee!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I just realised you really were the first to spot this Stror 'At Coot, last summer - archivesoutside.records.nsw.gov.au/happy-summer-hiatus-po... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/] At the risk of seeming greedy, maybe [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia]'s other Stror 'At Coot id can be posted too? - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp...

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: Of course we are so used to seeing the bridge now, but then they must have thought how unbelievably big this structure would be! and possibly so unneccessarily large compared to their needs at that time.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Two for the price of one! Thanks AG! And no they weren't missed - the first one was actually one of Jenny Sloggett's examples that kicked off the summer hiatus game find “The Stror ‘At Coot”, and the Harrington Lane one was spotted by me on December 20, 2011 at 7:16 pm (according to the comment date stamp). :) They were tagged but I'm off to note them too! UPDATE - I've gathered all the sightings together here: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/galleries/72157631965322586]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Equivalent artwork: Old Miller Street, Sydney (1925) by Lionel Lindsay - artsearch.nga.gov.au/Detail.cfm?IRN=92499

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Ahh yes of course! Thought it unlikely you'd've missed them! :)

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Another equivalent: Dawes Point (c.1855) by Frederick Garling - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au//item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=423592

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Brilliant equivalents - it  was literally a picturesque corner of Sydney.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/noctorum] That's great! I was about 50m too far south with the street view above. The pointy house with the balcony was about level with Parbury Lane - George Street did not originally have a kink in it under the Bridge ... Revised GoogleMapsStreetView
